t: Job 21
Job
Then*p Job replied:
“Listen*pn carefully to my words; let*ld this be the consolation you give me.
Bear*ln with me while I speak, and*ld after I have spoken, mock on.
“Is*pn my complaint directed to a human being? Why*ld should I not be impatient?
Look*ln at me and be appalled; clap*ld your hand over your mouth.
When*ln I think about this, I am terrified; trembling*ld seizes my body.
Why*ln do the wicked live on, growing*ld old and increasing in power?
They*ln see their children established around them, their*ld offspring before their eyes.
Their*ln homes are safe and free from fear; the*ld rod of God is not on them.
Their*ln bulls never fail to breed; their*ld cows calve and do not miscarry.
They*ln send forth their children as a flock; their*ld little ones dance about.
They*ln sing to the music of timbrel and lyre; they*ld make merry to the sound of the pipe.
They*ln spend their years in prosperity and*ld go down to the grave in peace.
Yet*ln they say to God, ‘Leave us alone! We*ld have no desire to know your ways.
Who*ln is the Almighty, that we should serve him? What*ld would we gain by praying to him?’
But*ln their prosperity is not in their own hands, so*ld I stand aloof from the plans of the wicked.
“Yet*pn how often is the lamp of the wicked snuffed out? How*ld often does calamity come upon them, the*ld fate God allots in his anger?
How*ln often are they like straw before the wind, like*ld chaff swept away by a gale?
It*ln is said, ‘God stores up the punishment of the wicked for their children.’ Let*ld him repay the wicked, so that they themselves will experience it!
Let*ln their own eyes see their destruction; let*ld them drink the cup of the wrath of the Almighty.
For*ln what do they care about the families they leave behind when*ld their allotted months come to an end?
“Can*pn anyone teach knowledge to God, since*ld he judges even the highest?
One*ln person dies in full vigor, completely*ld secure and at ease,
well*ln nourished in body, bones*ld rich with marrow.
Another*ln dies in bitterness of soul, never*ld having enjoyed anything good.
Side*ln by side they lie in the dust, and*ld worms cover them both.
“I*pn know full well what you are thinking, the*ld schemes by which you would wrong me.
You*ln say, ‘Where now is the house of the great, the*ld tents where the wicked lived?’
Have*ln you never questioned those who travel? Have*ld you paid no regard to their accounts—
that*ln the wicked are spared from the day of calamity, that*ld they are delivered from the day of wrath?
Who*ln denounces their conduct to their face? Who*ld repays them for what they have done?
They*ln are carried to the grave, and*ld watch is kept over their tombs.
The*ln soil in the valley is sweet to them; everyone*ld follows after them, and*ld a countless throng goes before them.
“So*pn how can you console me with your nonsense? Nothing*ld is left of your answers but falsehood!”
